title: At least two killed in Russian attacks on Ukraine’s Kharkiv, Sumy
snippets: Russia intensifies attacks on Ukraine as Kyiv for the first time accuses China of providing weapons to Moscow.
titles: At least two killed in Russian attacks on Ukraine’s Kharkiv, Sumy
summary: Russia has escalated its military offensive against Ukraine. Concurrently, for the first time, Ukraine has officially accused China of supplying weapons to Russia. This development marks a significant accusation in the ongoing conflict, indicating a potential shift in international dynamics related to the war.

title: US will 'move on' from Ukraine peace talks if no progress soon
snippets: The US Secretary of State's comments come as Ukraine says it took a first step towards signing a minerals deal with the US.
titles: US will 'move on' from Ukraine peace talks if no progress soon
summary: The US Secretary of State commented on Ukraine's announcement of taking the initial step toward signing a minerals deal with the United States. This development indicates a strengthening of economic ties between the two countries, particularly in the minerals sector.

title: ‘Ripple effect:’ In US, anti-immigrant policy strains child and eldercare
snippets: Immigrants are scared to show up to work, exacerbating a worker shortage in key industries.
titles: ‘Ripple effect:’ In US, anti-immigrant policy strains child and eldercare
summary: Immigrants' fear of showing up to work has intensified worker shortages in crucial industries. This situation highlights the significant role immigrants play in the workforce and the impact of their reduced participation.

title: Tariffs threaten to push auto insurance rates even higher
snippets: Between the slate of tariffs currently in effect and proposed tariffs on car parts, the cost of car ownership is rising. And that's true even if you're not in the market for a vehicle.
titles: Tariffs threaten to push auto insurance rates even higher
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful insights into the potential impact of tariffs on auto insurance rates, and raises awareness about the economic implications of trade policies.
summary: The current and proposed tariffs on car parts are leading to an increase in the cost of car ownership, affecting consumers regardless of whether they are looking to purchase a vehicle.

titles: US senator meets man mistakenly deported to El Salvador
summary: Salvadoran President Bukele has stated that Kilmar Ábrego García, who is currently embroiled in a legal battle in the United States, will remain in custody in El Salvador. This decision comes amidst the ongoing US court proceedings involving García.

titles: BREAKING: John, Amy Flynn out as Harbor Springs basketball coaches
summary: Harbor Springs School District has officially announced that John and Amy Flynn, the head basketball coaches, will not be returning for the next season. This confirmation was made to the News-Review on Friday.

title: NHL sets attendance record, surpassing 23M fans
snippets: The NHL reported an attendance figure of 23,014,458 across the 1,312-game regular season, setting a league record for the third consecutive season.
The NHL set an attendance record in 2024-25, drawing 23,014,458 fans over 1,312 regular-season games, the league announced Friday.
titles: NHL sets attendance record, surpassing 23M fans
NHL sets attendance record, surpassing 23 million fans
summary: The NHL achieved a record attendance of 23,014,458 across 1,312 regular-season games in the 2024-25 season, marking the highest attendance in the league's history for the third consecutive year.

summary: The 2025 men's college basketball season has seen significant coaching changes across various teams. The coaching carousel is almost complete, with numerous teams announcing new hires or departures. This reshuffle aims to enhance team performance and achieve better results in future seasons.

title: Europe, U.S. Central Banks Have Taken Different Paths In Trump Era
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • The European Central Bank has continued cutting interest rates this year, while its American counterpart, the Federal Reserve, has held them steady.
  • The Fed has been reluctant to cut rates as President Donald Trump imposes tariffs on global trading partners, which could reignite high inflation.
  • European central bankers have been more concerned that the trade tensions with the U.S. could slow their countries' economies.


In 2025, the European Central Bank and its American counterpart have taken starkly different approaches to monetary policy.

The ECB has continued to slash interest rates, while the Fed has held them steady. The diverging paths came into focus more sharply on Thursday when the ECB lowered its benchmark rate by a quarter point, the seventh decrease since June.

By contrast, Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell made public comments the same day, suggesting U.S. central bankers are in no hurry to cut the key fed funds rate. The Fed has cut its rate by 1 percentage point from its peak last year, and held it steady since December, while the ECB has lowered its own by 1.75 percentage points.

Powell's remarks elicited a response from President Donald Trump, who accused Powell of acting too slowly to cut rates, falling behind Europe in lowering borrowing costs and boosting the economy.

However, economists said the difference was mainly caused by Trump's own policies, especially his sprawling and unpredictable campaign of tariffs on trading partners. In the years leading up to the tariffs, the two central banks largely moved in tandem, reacting to similar economic currents.

Forecasters and investors widely expect the tariffs to push up the cost of living, making Fed officials reluctant to cut interest rates for fear of reigniting inflation. European officials, meanwhile, are more concerned with an economic slowdown, especially since the tariffs could hurt exports to the U.S.

"Every central bank is dealing with the complications arising from the trade war, a six-sigma event," wrote Douglas Porter, chief economist at BMO Capital Markets, in a note Thursday. "The response to the tariff uncertainty varies depending on how sensitive the economy is to U.S. trade, and the respective starting points for growth and inflation."

Ernie Tedeschi, director of economics at the Budget Lab at Yale, emphasized the specific differences between the U.S. and its European counterparts in a post on social media platform X, referring to President Trump's seeming resurrection of 19th-century-style mercantilist economic policies.

"Europe didn't raise their tariffs to Gilded Age levels, so they're not facing the price pressure the Fed is," he said.
titles: Europe, U.S. Central Banks Have Taken Different Paths In Trump Era
summary: In 2025, the European Central Bank (ECB) and the Federal Reserve (Fed) have adopted differing monetary policies in response to economic conditions and trade tensions. The ECB has reduced its interest rates by 1.75 percentage points, including a quarter-point cut on April 17, aiming to stimulate their economies amidst concerns over trade tensions with the U.S. and potential economic slowdown. Conversely, the Fed has maintained its rate steady since December, following a 1 percentage point cut from its peak last year, due to concerns that cutting rates further could reignite inflation, especiall

title: Trump will abandon Ukraine peace talks ‘in days’ without progress, warns Rubio
snippets: US secretary of state’s warning came hours before JD Vance expressed optimism a breakthrough was close
titles: Trump will abandon Ukraine peace talks ‘in days’ without progress, warns Rubio
summary: Hours before JD Vance expressed optimism about a potential breakthrough, the US Secretary of State issued a warning regarding the situation. Despite Vance's hopeful outlook, the Secretary of State's caution underscores the complexity and uncertainty of the circumstances.

title: ‘We had to buy them’: old emails haunt Zuckerberg in high-stakes trial
snippets: Meta founder’s antitrust defence rests on showing that TikTok is rapidly expanding in his main market
titles: ‘We had to buy them’: old emails haunt Zuckerberg in high-stakes trial
summary: The defense strategy for Meta's founder in an antitrust case centers on demonstrating TikTok's significant growth in his primary market. This argument aims to counter claims of monopolistic behavior by highlighting the competitive presence of TikTok.

title: Companies Are Beating Q1 Earnings Estimates So Far. Some Big Results Are Up Next
snippets:
The first-quarter earnings season is off to a softish start by some measures, according to new research, but another quarter of year-on-year growth still looks likely. 

Based on preliminary results—just 12% of S&P 500 companies have reported results so far, according to an analysis released late Thursday by FactSet—70% of reporting companies in the benchmark index have come in above Street estimates. That’s below the five- and 10-year averages, FactSet said.

Earnings have come in 6.1% above estimates, also below the five- and 10-year averages, according to FactSet. (The historical numbers are based on actual results for the full past quarters.)

The S&P 500's first-quarter results are still projected to grow for a seventh consecutive quarter, according to FactSet, which said the “blended” earnings growth rate through Thursday—meaning a combination of the results already in and the estimates for those yet to arrive—was 7.2% so far. 

Investor attention will likely turn in large part to some Magnificent Seven results due next week—Tesla (TSLA) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOG) are scheduled to report—but the earnings calendar will be busy with several other companies like Verizon (VZ), PepsiCo (PEP), Intel (INTC) and Boeing (BA) also set to announce their own numbers. 

Health insurer Elevance (ELV) is also on the calendar, its results expected days after UnitedHealth (UNH) reported weaker-than-expected results and cut its outlook, sending its stock plunging Thursday. (Yesterday was the last trading day of a holiday-shortened week.)
titles: Companies Are Beating Q1 Earnings Estimates So Far. Some Big Results Are Up Next
summary: The first quarter of the S&P 500 earnings season has started with 70% of the initial 12% of companies reporting earnings above estimates, although this is below the five- and ten-year averages. Despite this, a seventh consecutive quarter of year-on-year growth is projected, with a 7.2% blended earnings growth rate so far. Key upcoming earnings reports include major companies like Tesla, Alphabet, Verizon, PepsiCo, Intel, and Boeing. Elevance's results are also anticipated, following UnitedHealth's weaker-than-expected performance and revised outlook, which impacted its stock negatively.

title: Placate or retaliate? Starmer and Carney are both right on Trump
snippets: The long goodbye to the US-led world order means leaders must tread carefully
titles: Placate or retaliate? Starmer and Carney are both right on Trump
summary: The global shift away from a US-led world order requires cautious navigation by international leaders. This transition marks a significant change in global politics and necessitates careful strategy and diplomacy to manage the evolving landscape.

title: Artificial light pollution could fuel growth of toxic algal blooms
snippets: The "skyglow" produced when light from cities bounces off clouds can help cyanobacteria and other aquatic microbes grow at night
titles: Artificial light pollution could fuel growth of toxic algal blooms
summary: Skyglow, the phenomenon where city lights reflect off clouds, has been found to aid the nighttime growth of cyanobacteria and other aquatic microbes. This effect occurs as the artificial light increases, providing conditions conducive for microbial growth during periods that would naturally be dark.

title: Hot methane seeps could support life beneath Antarctica’s ice sheet
snippets: Microbial communities feeding on geothermal methane seeps beneath the Antarctic ice sheet could resemble life-supporting environments on frozen worlds in our solar system and beyond
titles: Hot methane seeps could support life beneath Antarctica’s ice sheet
summary: Scientists have discovered microbial communities thriving on methane seeps beneath the Antarctic ice sheet, suggesting similar life-supporting environments could exist on frozen worlds in our solar system and beyond. This discovery highlights the potential for life in extreme conditions and may guide future extraterrestrial life searches.

title: Most accurate space clock to launch – and count down to destruction
snippets: A network of Earth's best clocks will be synchronised with the most accurate one ever sent into space. But the device has a short shelf life: it will burn up in the atmosphere at the end of the decade as the ISS deorbits
titles: Most accurate space clock to launch – and count down to destruction
summary: A network of Earth's most precise clocks will be synchronized with the most accurate clock ever launched into space, which is aboard the International Space Station (ISS). This synchronization aims to enhance global timekeeping standards. However, the space-based clock has a limited operational lifespan, as it is expected to burn up in the atmosphere by the end of the decade when the ISS is scheduled to deorbit.

title: Slices of wood can filter bacteria and microplastics from water
snippets: Water filters made from untreated wood can remove more than 99 per cent of particles, taking out many harmful bacteria and microplastics
titles: Slices of wood can filter bacteria and microplastics from water
summary: Researchers have developed water filters made from untreated wood that can eliminate over 99% of particles, including harmful bacteria and microplastics. This discovery offers a potentially sustainable and efficient method for purifying water.

title: Will we ever have confirmation of life outside our solar system?
snippets: The report of possible biosignatures on the exoplanet K2-18b is exciting, but we are a long way from establishing beyond doubt that there is life on such a distant world
titles: Will we ever have confirmation of life outside our solar system?
summary: Scientists have reported potential biosignatures on the exoplanet K2-18b, indicating possible signs of life. However, they caution that conclusive evidence of life on this distant planet is still far from being confirmed.
